Controller

It’s job is to construct the model and publish it to the view.

scripts/main.js


			.controller("AboutCtrl", 
				function(model) {

				  console.log(model);

				});

The Controllers dictate change in the model. This was the hardest concept for me to grasp. What we're saying is anytime something is supposed to change we will use a Controller to handle that.

Controllers are really just functions stored in an object. They have the added benefit of access to the global model variable and auto-updating the View after they run.

scripts/main.js


			.route("/about", {

				  templateUrl: "views/about.html",
				  controller: "AboutCtrl"

				});

Logically there are two common instances in which you would want to change data on your page. The first being when the URL changes. This often reflects a serious shift in the current UI and probably requires new data.

Lure.js handles this with "routes". You can assign a Controller that will run whenever the URL matches a specific string. The data the assigned Controller receives will be merged with the listed template of choice.

views/controller.html


			<pre x-highlight class="javascript"><code>
			.controller("AboutCtrl", 
				function(model) {

				  console.log(model);

				});
			</code></pre>

The second instance of model change is UI interaction. Lure.js handles this with DOM Controllers for your HTML. They can add events, change values, assign classes, and even call other controllers.

You add these to your HTML elements as attributes using the x-ControllerName="value" syntax. When you add one of these attributes to an element the "ControllerName" Controller will run when that element is parsed.

scripts/main.js


			.controller("highlight", 
				function(model, el, value, controllers) {

					hljs.highlightBlock(el, "&nbsp;");

				})

The named Controller will be passed pointers to the model object, the element that called it, the optional "value" field, and the list of all the Controllers.

You can do whatever you decide with this info to hopefully change your Model and then watch as your View is automatically updated.
